abstract.text: An object that organizes all of the active SpriteKit content.

inlineContent.text: object represents a scene of content in SpriteKit. A scene is the root node in a tree of SpriteKit nodes (
). These nodes provide content that the scene animates and renders for display. To display a scene, you present it from an

and enables certain effects to apply to the entire scene. Though applying effects to an entire scene can be an expensive operation, creativity, and ingenuity may help you find some interesting ways to use effects.

abstract.text: A visual WatchKit element that displays a SpriteKit scene.
Add high-performance 2D content with smooth animations to your app, or create a game with a high-level set of 2D game-based tools.
A node that renders its children into a separate buffer, optionally applying an effect, before drawing the final result.
The base class of all SpriteKit nodes.
An object that renders a scene into a custom Metal rendering pipeline and drives the scene update cycle.
An object that organizes all of the active SpriteKit content.
The point in the view’s frame that corresponds to the scene’s origin.
The AVFoundation audio engine used to play audio from audio nodes contained in the scene.
The background color of the scene.
The camera node in the scene that determines what part of the scene’s coordinate space is visible in the view.
Converts a point from view coordinates to scene coordinates.
Converts a point from scene coordinates to view coordinates.
A delegate to be called during the animation loop.
Tells your app to peform any necessary logic after constraints are applied.
Tells you when the scene’s size has changed.
Tells your app to peform any necessary logic after scene actions are evaluated.
Tells your app to peform any necessary logic after the scene has finished all of the steps required to process animations.
Tells you when the scene is presented by a view.
Tells your app to peform any necessary logic after physics simulations are performed.
Initializes a new scene object.
A node used to determine the position of the listener for positional audio in the scene.
The physics simulation associated with the scene.
A setting that defines how the scene is mapped to the view that presents it.
Tells you when the scene is presented.
Creates and returns a new scene object.
The dimensions of the scene, in points.
Tells your app to perform any app-specific logic to update your scene.
The view that is currently presenting the scene.
Tells you when the scene is about to be removed from a view.
Methods that, when implemented, allow any class to participate in the SpriteKit render loop callbacks.
The modes that determine how the scene’s area is mapped to the view that presents it.
A view subclass that renders a SpriteKit scene.
A definition for a deformation of nodes that conform to
A protocol for objects that can be warped and animated by an
Compare the different ways to display a SpriteKit scene.
Enable your node to respond to user input, like touches or mouse clicks.
Load a scene that you configure in Xcode’s scene editor.

Define the appearance or layout of scene content.

abstract.text: Identifies scene classes from other frameworks that support embedded GameplayKit information.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A set of methods for converting between different frames of reference on a screen.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
An object that can become focused.
The container responsible for providing geometric context to focus items within a given focus environment.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A type whose values can be implicitly or explicitly copied.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.

abstract.text: Callbacks occur every frame, telling you when to perform app logic.
Instead of subclassing a scene to respond to update life-cycle events, assign a delegate to field them.
